First , let me say the “Crash Course” series is an informative, fun and fast paced resource that PBS should be proud to air. I have one question. It’s stated in the “ How Power…” episode that transformers only work with alternating current. In my opinion, this isn’t true. Automobiles, motorcycles, watercraft and a few other examples use step up transformers in their d/c supplied ignition systems. Instead of saying transformers ‘only on work with a/c power supplies’ perhaps change the statement to transformers only work with a cycling or digital power supply. In these ignition systems, 12vdc is apply to the primary side of the ignition coil. And weather a PCM commands the circuit open or a set of breaker points disconnects the coil from ground, the same thing is happening. The magnetic field in the primary (12vdc) coil collapses, inducing a “stepped up “ voltage (40,000vdc) in the secondary winding, and this fires the spark plug. Thanks for the great videos and for your time- Jason Burchell

Transformers are used to increase or decrease current/voltage. Step up increases voltage and decreases current  Step down decreases voltage and increases current. Step up transformers are used for transporting electricity for long distances because Ploss=I^2R (a lower current is used to decrease power loss) Step down transformers are just used to decrease voltage so it is suitable for certain appliances. Also transformers are made of two coils wrapped around a laminated iron core. That means the iron core is cut into thin sheets and separated by an electrical insulating material. Laminated cores are used to reduce the production of eddy currents. Less eddy currents = less energy lost as heat. Does all that make sense? I have a test tomorrow so I’m just dumping some stuff in my brain.

I have a technical correction, although it's not important to the grand idea of the lecture. In the US houses are actually wired for 240 volts, from the transformer to the junction box, by wiring the house across two phases of power. (Which larger appliances will use directly.) Then power is distributed throughout a house by connecting the electrical loads to a single live wire, and returning through a neutral wire to the transformer; in this way splitting the house into two 120 half phases.

I'm an EE and I can only just barely follow everything she says as she jumps from topic to topic. If I didn't already know where she was going, I'd be lost. This serves as more of a refresher course than an introduction because of the speed at which she speaks, the lack of diagrams (I know there are several, but there really need to be more for new students), and the complexity of the subject matter.   The core concepts, like induction, are really hard to grasp, even if you watched the last video about induction. It takes lots of practice problems and demonstrations for engineers to learn this stuff in school. I realize this is "crash" courses, but there's something to be said for practice. It helps solidify ideas in our heads. I don't expect them to start assigning worksheets, but this needs to be in a better format. I don't think it's reasonable to expect everyone that wants to learn this to have to watch the video 4 or 5 times before the concepts start sinking in.  I actually think the equations are a bad way to go. If you need the equations, you should look somewhere else for the math. If you came here for the concepts, the equations aren't going to be used. In the mean time, they confuse most of your audience.

if you put DC to a transformer, current doesnt change, thus nothing comes out the other side, so transformers dont work with DC, thus making AC ideal for generating the higher voltage. The ability of higher voltages to travel further relates to the ohms law, with the wasted power being P=R*I^2, so a lower current (that you get with higher voltage, for the same output power) causes much less losses in the wire.

Unclenate1000   In the primary coil of a transformer, changing current causes a changing magnetic field.  Then, the changing magnetic field causes a voltage in the secondary coil.  In order for a transformer to work, the magnetic field has to be changing.  (See the previous video in this series on induction.)  The voltage in the secondary is related to the voltage in the primary by the ratio of the number of turns in each.   Example:  If I feed 120 volt AC into a transformer whose primary coil has 10 turns, and whose secondary coil has 20 turns, the voltage on the secondary will be 240 volts AC.  If we hook the secondary to a power consuming device, such as a light bulb, then current will flow.  The current in the secondary will be 1/2 of the current in the primary.   Power is current times voltage, so the power transferred by the primary is equal to the power induced in the secondary.

Unclenate1000   As urjaman0 wrote, the resistive losses in a transmission line are proportional to the square of the current, but are independent of the voltage.  Power, though, is voltage times current, so you can increase the power transmitted on a line, without increasing the resistive loss, by increasing voltage.  Power is what customers want and pay for, so increasing the voltage on a transmission line is a way to transmit more of what the customers want, without increasing losses in the line.  Note that there are limits to raising the voltage on a transmission line.  An obvious one is that at high enough voltage, an arc will form between the conductors, not a good thing.  I often wish my electric lawn mower ran on 240 volts rather than 120.  The same current passing through my house wiring and extension cord would deliver twice as much power to the mower.  That would change a slightly anemic device into a fully practical one.

tabaks   I am a chemist.  I earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in chemistry, not a doctorate.  The material presented in this Crash Course Physics series is straight out of high school physics, except for the little bit of calculus used, which is sometimes omitted from high school physics.  I have in front of me the textbook I used in high school physics in 1971-72.  It contains the same material presented in this video, although the textbook goes into considerably more detail.  A modern high school Advanced Placement physics class would certainly cover this.

I agree, the material is not particularly heavy or advanced. However, I believe the way the information has been presented is not conducive to getting viewers excited and interested in physics, which I think is an objective that Crash Course is capable of doing Really well. They can help people understand how these things fit in to our lives, and then the person is free to pursue more in-depth topics like: "Exactly how much power is generated from a turbine?" "How do step-down transformers work"  They can talk about physics in general without getting bogged down in the calculation details, in my opinion.  I am however willing to concede that maybe my expectations are off for the desired focus of this series. If I wanted to introduce someone to electricity and the power grid and how it all works together, I should maybe be looking for a CC series labeled 'Technology' or 'Technology in our Lives' rather than 'Physics'. If the point is to get someone  started on high school physics, then this would be a good start to introducing the topic.

Um... Pretty sure there are plenty of videos out there already that will explain how the power gets to one's house without the formulas.  However, it is the addition of the formulas which will allow one to actually learn and apply physics. Without it, it's just performing magic without knowing how to tweak the process to achieve a desired goal.

The loss is resistance. The loss is heat generated which is proportional to i^2 times r. (the wire is a very long resistor)  When the voltage is increased, current is reduced, so the i^2 factor becomes smaller.
Wait, doesn't a higher voltage mean a higher current? As in I=V/R?

A higher voltage results in a lower current as power is V*I and must be conserved. YOu cannot have more power on 1 side of the transformer than the other. They must be equal. So as V goes up, I goes down

+Collin Barker Well strictly speaking P(input) = P(output) + P(loss) all transformers do have a power loss due primarily to internal resistance in the wire and also to parasitic currents induced in nearby conductors hell if they are sat near the ground and the Earth is damp they even loose some to the friction incurred when water molecules rotate to align their dipoles with the changing field.

Don't use the term "flux" before explaining it or pointing to another video. You're also missing the "why to care". By having High tension (High Voltage) power lines, we reduce the losses in transmission, as the power lost in the lines is to the square of the current. Higher voltage, less current.
Volton better be mentioned.

The narration describes alternating current, but the animation shows a generator with a commutator.  A commutated generator produces current only in one direction.  It's not strictly DC, as from a battery, because it pulses with a sine shape, but it certainly is not alternating current.  This is an error that needs to be corrected.  When the animations conflict with the narration, some of the audience will certainly be confused.
